On Tuesday 24 June 2003 20:57, areider wrote:
> I dont want to get too OT but maybe a specific example
> will help. 

Yes.

> I'm now in early development of a mapping a business
> object model in TOPLink. I want to evaluate expressions which read my
> objects from the db to test my mappings.  If that doesnt blow up (and
> it does, a LOT, right now), I want to play around with that instance
> in an inspector, send messages to it, fix the toString(), test lazy
> instantiation of its parts, add some behavior, debug, etc, all in the
> context of a live instance. In short I want to _interact_ with the
> object.

If I get you right, you use JUnit (or tests written for JUnit) like you 
could use any other code: to do something / create some state, display 
some data. You do not assert something as for automated testing, right?
In fact you are debugging or developing, not testing or doing TDD?

In this case I'd agree with JB: use JUnit if it helps getting your job 
done. I can not (yet?) see what benefits JUnit could bring comapred to 
plain Java, though.

> However since I am going to the trouble to create this test code
> which produces those objects, I would like to institutionalize those
> snippets into a test suite so I and other team members can reuse them
> easily in the same manner. That's why I dont want the code in a
> scrapbook window. I'm less interested in the automated test aspect
> right now.

Right now means during development / debugging, right?
Looks like you are playing around and getting familiar with Toplink?

> I mean I want to elevate my test artifacts from workspacewindow
> snippets to code which is managed by the version control system (Envy
> etc), available to team members, etc. And yes for automated testing
> eventually.

Maybe you could turn those things you found out into automated test 
cases?

Robert
